items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The Yeo and Parrett rivers are still high, sustained by the high flows coming down the catchments today following the recent rains. The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.89m and steady. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.06m and rising slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3m; the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m; the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Drayton above 8.8m. We are unable to pump while the River Yeo is full. A moderate band of rain is forecast tomorrow, Sunday 07/12/2025, which will cause rivers to rise. Following a drier day on Monday, a large band of heavy persistent rain is forecast for Tuesday, which will cause further flooding impacts. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We will resume pumping when river levels allow. Avoid driving through flood water. Refer to the local authority website for information on local road closures. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Saturday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 06 December 2025 from 10:30, following the 10mm of rain that fell on Friday. 
Minor impact flooding could affect fields, roads, and gardens, including near Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. Only minimal flood impacts affecting fields are expected in Alfriston. River levels on the Cuckmere near Cowbeech are already falling. Scattered showers are possible Saturday and Sunday. River levels and flood risk should begin to initially reduce in Hellingly by 13:00 on 06/12/2025, and by 22:00 on 06/12/2025 in Alfriston. River levels should return nearer to normal by Sunday evening. Widespread rain forecast Tuesday 9/12/2025 could increase flood risk again. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Mill Ln Church Rd Hellingly, North St Alfriston). 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 07 December 2025 from 16:00, following a lot of rain (60mm) in December. 
Minor flooding could affect fields and gardens near Fittleworth Mill. At Lodsbridge near Selham, the river is higher than normal, but has peaked. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels are already falling. Light rain is forecast on Sunday, clearing by mid afternoon. River levels in all communities are expected to rise a small amount again on Sunday 07/12/2025, but flood risk is not predicted between Liss and Midhurst. River levels and flood risk should initially begin to reduce in Fittleworth by 12:00 Monday 08/12/2025. However, more rain on Tuesday could bring flood risk to all communities. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. 
This message will be updated by 5:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high due to recent rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend, and the risk of flooding continues. Flooding is possible on 06 December 2025. 

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow.  

Predicted peaks:- Leintwardine 1.4m to 1.6m 07/12 AM, Onibury 2.2m to 2.3m 06/12 early morning, Corve 2.5m to 2.7m 06/12 midday. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

items.message: River levels have fallen on most rivers in West Somerset, but remain high on the Washford River, which is still just above the Flood Alert level. Some moderate rain tomorrow, Sunday 07 December 2025, will likely keep the Washford River at Alert level. Other rivers in the area may rise moderately, according to the current forecast. There remains a risk of flooding tomorrow, Sunday in low lying land and roads, particularly near the Washford River and tributaries. Following a drier day on Monday, a large band of heavy persistent rain is forecast for Tuesday, which will cause further flooding impacts. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 07 December 2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
"River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 03:30 AM on 07/12/2025, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is 106 cubic metres per second and is rising slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 12 hours."

High tides on Sunday may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible for 2 hours either side of Sunday's early morning tide at 00:15 on 07/12/2025. 
The weather increases tide table values by 0.13 m. Total forecast tide is 6.03 metres Chart Datum (2.98 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Light South Westerly Force 4 wind. Small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and Climping Street Car Park. Sunday's tide at 12:30 07/12/2025 is forecast to be 20 cm higher (3.18 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected both tides. Flood risk should reduce next week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . We routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. 
Consider activating any flood protection products you may have . Access could be restricted. Take care if visiting Climping beach. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves over the next three days may lead to flooding.  

Flooding is possible over high tides from the evening of Saturday 6th December to the morning of Tuesday 9th December.  

Low lying coastal roads, promenades, car parks and harbours may be flooded. 

High tide at Plymouth on Saturday evening is at 18:42 and on Sunday morning at 07:00, times of high water will vary along the coast.  Forecast total high tide levels are 2.55mAOD and 2.85mAOD respectively. Expect tide levels along the coast to be around 0.3m above tide table level. Strong force 6 westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 3.0m are forecast.  

The high tide of most concern is Sunday morning and flood warnings may be issued.  

We are closely monitoring the situation .  

Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded .  

This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

The River Tone at Currymoor Pumping Station is still high. While it is currently marginally below Alert level (Hookbridge Spillway), the current high tide sequence will raise the river level again later today. The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.42m and stable. Water enters Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway if this level exceeds 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.89m and stable. Cutts Road floods if this level is above 5.75m, and New Road floods if this level is above 6.18m. We are unable to pump while the Tone is full. Some moderate rain is forecast tomorrow, Sunday 07 December 2025, with limited impacts. Following a drier day on Monday, a large band of heavy persistent rain is forecast for Tuesday, which will cause further flooding impacts. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We will resume pumping when river levels allow. Take care and avoid driving through flood water. Refer to the local authority website for information on local road closures. This message will be updated by 3:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Hayling and South Eastoke seafront
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding on Sunday. 
Flooding is expected for 2 hours either side of Sunday afternoon's tide at 12:35 on 07/12/2025.   
The weather increases tide table values by 0.42 m. Total forecast tide is 5.35 metres Chart Datum (2.62 mAOD) at Portsmouth. Strong South Westerly Force 5 wind. It is possible there will be water in the prom at high tide in the Eastoke Corner area. Local teams are monitoring the beach condition at Eastoke over the weekend for any further actions. Monday's tide at 01:12 on 08/12/2025 is forecast to be 37 cm lower (2.25 mAOD). High water levels are forecast to continue for the next few days, until Tuesday 09/12/2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Activate any flood protection products you may have . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Yeovilton to Huish Episcopi
items.message: Levels remain high on the River Yeo following the recent heavy persistent rain. While levels have dropped further up at Pen Mill, river and drain levels are still high further downstream in the areas around Ilchester, Long Load and Huish Episcopi. Therefore the need for this Alert remains. Areas at risk include the A37 south and A303 south west of Ilchester, the Ilchester to Limington road and road to Ilchester Meads. There is also a risk of flooding at Hainbury Mill. Water may reach the ringbanks at Ilchester Meads. Some moderate rain is forecast tomorrow, Sunday 07 December 2025, with limited impacts. Following a drier day on Monday, a large band of heavy persistent rain is forecast for Tuesday, which will cause further flooding impacts. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. We are checking defences, bridges, culverts and screens. We will pump when river levels allow. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Act on your flood plan if you haven't already. This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 07 December 2025 or as the situation changes.
